Entry.1:
The new year entered with mirth and merriment in our hut to the swirl of pipes etc.

The ground is snow covered but the day is beautifully fine. We are now at Dranoutre, Belgium about two miles over the French border and about three miles from Ballieul in France. This morning much temporary sickness prevails among the troops as a result of excess of mirth etc. last night. Personally I am O.K. & had only a glass of champagne last night. Living a quiet & uneventful life round a field Hospital.
Entry.2: Still beautifully fine but the thaw has set in.
Entry.3: First Australian mail for ages. Snow last night but another beautiful day. Aerial activity increased as well as artillery activity. The thaw is gradually set in.
Entry.4: Walk to Ballieul see Verner en route & was pulled up by the A P M for not saluting. However he was very decent and nothing was said.
Entry.5: Still fine weather. The snow has again and the roads are like glass & vehicles slipping all over the place. Front still quiet. Our bread ration has been cut down and the shortage has been made up with biscuits. Our unit canteen is now very profitable and from the profits we have money expended on us & food bought to make up rations.
Entry.6: Very cold but fine. Church at night at the Y.M.C.A.
Entry.8: On guard for 24 hours. A very heavy snow storm again last night but it is freezing again.
Entry.9: Snowing very heavily again. Attend lecture by Sir Richard Lodge, Professor History at Edinburgh University on the "Unity of Italy" & the "Unity of Germany", a contrast. The lecture was lucid and I think it is a great thing for the troops & I only hope it is a forerunner of more.
Entry.11:
Another lecture on the "Work of the Navy" by Mr. Bennett, member of the Naval League.

The snow except in sheltered places has almost disappeared.
Entry.12: Pay day. Nothing to report. An old fashioned picture show to-night at Y.M.C.A., pictures I saw ten years ago. "Padres" in the army in the field are a force and we have not seen one for over a year.
Entry.13:
Beautiful fine day & a walk to Ballieul this afternoon. Nothing at all of interest.

For about an hour I watched the ‘planes landing, rising and stunting over the ‘drome at Ballieul. The more I see of the machines the more I marvel at them.
Entry.14: Last night was very cold & freezing but early this morning was quite warm and the ground was snow covered to a depth of six inches. Not a breath of wind and the result is the snow is heavy on the trees & the landscape presents the same faireyland appearance as it did about three weeks ago. Snowballing in force. A walk, very slippery, to Ballieul again. News that "Lea Brook" has been sold.
Entry.15:
A true winters day.

A heavy westerly wind blowing up gusts of heavy rain in intervals, raining all day. Not cold but the prospects are of more rain.
Entry.16: Weather very boisterous this morning but died down this afternoon & turned out sunny. A fatigue trip to Lindenhoek near Kemmel.
Entry.17: An "evening in Egypt" with a lecturer at Y.M.C.A. who gave us a lantern lecture on Egypt, Cairo & surroundings prominent. Weather still bad, wet and snowing.
Entry.18:
Weather dull.

A walk to Neuve Eglise & look over the ruins. The place has been much knocked about since June ’16 but is not shelled much now, since Messines Ridge is in British hands.
Entry.19: This morning a balloon at Neuve Eglise broke away from its moorings & floated away over the Bosche lines. The observors came out in parachutes, & our anti aircraft guns tried by very rotten shooting to destroy the sausage in vain. Weather cloudy. Heavy bombardment on the right.
Entry.20:
In a sincere & eloquent speech, maiden speech, Mr. Smallwood in the House of Commons on Friday, drew attention to the gros mismanagement in the Army., He instanced his own personal cases of his two sons & he called "for a soul in the army something human". He said that he would rather a stoppage of any reinforcements until the authorities could use them properly. It is this idea which moved me against conscription. Weather raining a little & generally cloudy but warm.

Heavy bombardment on right.
Entry.21: Rather exciting last night. The Colonels hut was burnt down last night & all his clothes etc. were burnt & completely destroyed.
Entry.22: Weather wet though warm. Day still spent in fatigue reading & playing cards & occasionally going to the pictures or a concert.
Entry.23: Weather still dull but warm. Ordinary routine of camp life. A lecture on Armegeddon developed into a very dry sermon & bored me to death.
Entry.24: Beautifully fine day, plenty of aerial activity. Pictures at night.
Entry.25:
A beautiful day.

A night at Pictures & "Sentimental Blokes" (late Kookaburras). Very decent.
Entry.26: Usual camp routine. A Walk to Neuve Eglise on beautiful day. Tonight I watched a P.M. on a case of alcholic poisoning. The first I have seen & last I want to see.
Entry.27:
Nothing at all happened to-day.

It has been foggy & cold all day. We move in a couple of days but only just behind Ballieul.
Entry.29: Moving has begun & we are taking over from the 9th, about one mile from Ballieul & next to the Australian airdrome. Weather simply glorious.
Entry.30: We move tomorrow. The gear has been partly moved today. The glorious weather continues.
Entry.31: Move tonight to Ravelsberg about ½ mile from Ballieul.
Entry.32: Weather wet & foggy. The freezing cold & the fog have caused the trees to be covered with ice & present the same fairyland appearance as previously.
Entry.33: In pack store. The thaw has set in & the ice on the trees is falling down very heavily. Aerial activity.
Entry.34:
Weather fine

From the Airdrome nearby a new bi plane has been on trial. Rumour has it that it is 90 feet across the wings & carries 1 ton of bombs. It is a tremendous size & has two sets of engines. Looks very stable but slow.
Entry.36: Still fine weather. A night at the Anzac Coves, Ballieul. They are shortly to go to London where they are to show. Our bread ration up to to-day has been white but to-day saw the advent of brown bread which is not at all bad.
Entry.40:
The orchestra’s concert tonight and very decent too.

George Eaton & Sgt. Sellers sang as usual, beautiful.

Sunday 10 February

Still at Ravelsberg D.R.’s in the pack store. Expect leave to Paris shortly.

1st Australian mail for ages.
Entry.42:
F. Co. Engineers. Victory for Ambulance 16-3.

About 25 German prisoners passed along the road this morning. Captured last night in raid.
Entry.43: Weather fine & warm. The raid by the 3rd Division was very successful, 37 prisoners, 100 killed by raiders & many by artillery preparation. Our casualties 22.
Entry.44:
Weather wet. Our unit weekly made its debut to-day and is very decent.

A fancy dress carnival is to come off on Friday.

Thursday 14 February

A football match to-day between 1st Field Ambulance & 1st Div. M.G. resulted in a victory for us. The match was very exciting & played on a muddy ground. The
Entry.45: match we have won in the Division Comp. A German balloon small floated over our lines & came down in our camp, had phamplets addressed to French inhabitants.
Entry.46: The Fancy Dress Carnival came off to-night and was a huge success. I went as a Staff Captain red facings & colours on Mr. Neave’s tunic & was adjudged very good. All were present, officers included & all costumes very good. Prizes were awarded for most comical dress & best couple. H. Long as a sister was great. Refreshments & a flashlight photo. Of course many were rather inked on whisky etc.
Entry.47: Beautiful day gloriously fine. A walk round the adjacent ‘drome where I saw many types of ‘planes as well as the Bosche Albatross brought down this morning.
Entry.49:
Still weather gloriously fine & moonlit nights favourable for night flying. Fritz comes over nightly & drops a few bombs in the vicinity of camp.

Tuesday February

Still beautiful weather.

Second match of Competition against Engineers ended in a win, 6-nil for the Ambulance. To-morrow’s match against
Entry.51: "Stiffness". Very wet day making the football ground at Metéren very wet & slippery. The match against 1st Battn. resulted in a heavy defeat for us 22-nil. The Battalion play was superior in all respects & the better team won.
Entry.52: Most glorious day. A Euchre party at night was a success, I winning six games of twelve.
Entry.53:
March winds are commencing. The "Sentimental Blokes" in Ballieul are still very good, the lady being more charming than ever. A violent bombardment on our left to-night.

Papers profesy a big German attack on this front but I don’t know whether it will eventuate.
Entry.54: Walk over to 4th D.S.C. & find George Petersen in & have a good evening with him.
Entry.55: The football team which visited Rouen came back tonight having defeated 2nd A.G.H. by 6-nil.
Entry.56: March winds with a vengeance. However Spring is coming & the hedges are breaking out into leaf.
Entry.59: Move to-morrow to Kemmel. We have to hand over all packs & patients to about two miles away. Working to 9 p.m. to-night, a rotten job.
Entry.60: "March comes in like a lion", snowing, raining etc. We moved to-day to Kemmell, Main Dressing Station. The village is certainly knocked about, but nothing in comparison to villages on the Somme. We move up to the line to-morrow but I think things will be quiet.
Entry.61:
Move up to a cross roads, locally known as the Brasserie, on the Ypres road & camp in dugouts in the brewery. We are a little north of Wycheate. The A.D.S. is about 1½ miles further on & I believe very comfy. The weather is cold, wet & miserable, snowing off & on. We go to the A.D.S. tomorrow on fatigue work. Heavy bombardment last night in consequence of a raid by Fritz in which we lost many men killed, etc. & "he" was successful.

Sunday 3 March

Dull with drizzling rain. We went to A.D.S. to-day at Woormezeele to work on completing dugouts. Very little is left of the village & some graves about mention
Entry.62: Battle of Ypres. I walked up to St. Eloi, of which nothing is left. The country is rather hilly & our people hold most of the high ground. Artillery lively in the afternoon but no casualties came through.
Entry.63: Another visit to A.D.S. on fatigue work on dugout, placing concrete slabs on the top.
Entry.64: At the Brasserie to-day which is fine in fact beautiful. Went to Kemmel M.D.S. for mail. Gas guard tonight.
Entry.65: On guard at Brasserie, between Kemmel & Ypres. The A.D.S. at Woormezeele is 3000 yards direct from Ypres & our line is above famous Hill 60.
Entry.66:
On fatigue at A.D.S., working on the dugout.

Last night Fritz shelled the line for four hours with "mustard gas" & about one hundred casualties to 9th Battn. was the result. Colonel, Adjutant, & Capt. Phillips (1st F. Amb.), M.O., were gassed. Some cases were very bad & came down on the light railway, eyes & other parts of the body were affected. The cases were pitiful. Glorious day.

Go up to the posts on Sunday.
Entry.67: Working on dugout at A.D.S. & it is just about complete. Weather glorious.
Entry.68: Beautiful day. Spring is here & to-night Summer time comes into operation, the clock put forward one hour. We go up to the line to-morrow in front of famous Hill 60.
Entry.69:
At Mount Sorrel relay post nearby Hill 60 & just to the right of Zillebeke Lake which can be seen from here. The morning was very quiet indeed but this afternoon some 5.9’s fell close about doing little other harm than covering my tunic & some blankets with mud. Coming up we crossed the Ypres-Commines Canal & in fact Ypres is not very far on our left. The line is a series of outposts, some good & others not too bright.

Our dugout was over a "pill box", but has been blown in & decently repaired.

Weather beautiful.
Entry.70: Very quiet on the front to-day. Infantry changed over last night, but no casualties. A raid about 11.30 p.m. on our right appeared to be in progress. Only two casualties so far from R.A.P. Beautiful day. Our post is the easiest I have yet been on & we push the patients on a tram line for about ¾ of a mile. The country about is hilly sloping away to Ypres on the north & has been much battered about in the Battle of Messines.
Entry.71:
Glorious day & very quiet except on Hill 60, which is intermittently shelled.

A beautiful day & Ypres Cloth Hall, Lake Zillebeke & a couple of ruined villages are plainly discernible on our left.
Entry.72:
Very quiet on the front, and what few casualties there are are from gas.

We are living well, & doing nothing. Our meals are far better than we get at camp & I am No. 4 & chef.
Entry.73: Wet to-day. In a raid last night by 10th & 12th Battns. on our left, fifty prisoners were brought in. Fritz dropped a few showers of whiz-bangs about our dugout to-day some close. They appear to have been a H.E. shell & a sneezing gas the object being to render one unable to wear the respirator. We opened a bombardment on Fritz to-night at 9.30 but so far no retaliation.
Entry.74:
A wounded case this morning. Fritz attempted a raid on our left this morning & we heard his barrage. No idea as to results. Glorious day. Fritz shelled our vicinity heavily for the greater part of the day but fruitlessly. Glorious day & Ypres stands out very distinctly. The 
German
 bombardment last night signified also a raid by Tommies on our left at 9.30 p.m. but no idea as to results.
Entry.75: A beautiful Spring day. Fritz shelled about our dugout this morning & to-night he is continuing it with heavy stuff & fifty yards away are the distance. No carries.
Entry.76: Very quiet on the front to-day up till about 5 p.m. when the Bosche guns began to speak in salvoes & sent gas all round us. The attack is still in progress at midnight. Beautiful clear day, much aerial work & a fine moonlit night. A view of the German line from the top of Mount Sorrel shows the town of Commines (?) (Warneton) almost intact the church spire showing out well.
Entry.77:
Beautiful day but warm & showing a slight tendency to rain. Fritz has shelled Hill 60 to-day all day with very heavy stuff & the valley between us & the hill has been covered with a smoke pall all day. It is the most vigorous bombardment of one place I have seen since Pozieres. The Gas is being sent over to-night in small quantities & last night we had a carry through it. Heaviest gas attack I have seen but only one or two casualties were the results. I doubt whether the bombardment of Hill 60 caused many casualties.

Relieved to-morrow.
Entry.78:
Raining all day to-day making things muddy & miserable. We were relieved this morning & are now back at Voormezeele Advanced Dressing Station.

Either last night or the (? night) previous night Fritz dropped a shell in the back store at the M.D.S. at Kemmell, eight miles or so behind the line. Johns was in at the time & apart from almost being hurled out the roof he escaped with a gash in the face & a broken nose.

20th March

I have just seen a remarkable order issued by the O.C., 3rd Field Ambulance to whom we are attached to the effect that in the event of heavy shelling of the A.D.S. all except on special duty are to evacuate the place & retire to Brasserie for instructions.
Entry.79: At Vormeezeele I went for a bath. Though wet this morning it is now beautifully fine & moonlit. Apparently this much advertised German offensive is not to be delayed too long but I think the main attack will be delivered against the French. However the artillery activity on this front has shown a marked increase during the last week or so. He is shelling heavily all the back areas here, Kemmel & as far back as Balliel, Meteren, Strazeele, Hazebrouck, etc. On our part our artillery defence is marked & even behind of our 25" & 12" guns are batteries of 18 pdrs. Such preparations for a German blow I haven’t seen before. Rumour has it that notice has been given to inhabitants of villages near the line to evacuate & also that the M.D.S. at Kemmel should be moved. I can’t say what is in the rumours. Rumour about spies are also rife.
Entry.80: Beautiful day. Last night Fritz drenched the front with gas again & many cases are coming through, also wounded. Fritz is still continuing his shelling the back areas & to-day I went to the M.D.S. at Kemmel just in time to see eight H.V. shells land in the camp grounds. In fact he has been shelling Kemmel vigorously, always in the Hospital grounds & our people are evacuating it to-day. The back store has been blown up for a second time.
Entry.81:
Very quiet day at A.D.S., practically no shelling.

Rumour is to hand that the German offensive has commenced & they have attacked the British & French fronts on many mile fronts. It is said that the French have repulsed all attacks but that Bullecourt, Lagnicourt & Havrincourt have been taken from the British. Whether these rumours are correct I cannot say.
Entry.82: On fatigue work building dugouts at Spoil bank, on the Ypres-Comines canal. Everything very quiet, except that Fritz shelled St. Eloi. Glorious spring day. Rumours still rife as to German offensive. No reliable information.
Entry.83:
Beautiful day.

The Ludinoff Offensive has developed & rumour has it that he has advanced to a depth of two to fourteen miles into the Somme area attacking from Arras to La Fere, against the English & French. Apparently some Australians are going down & to-day we are preparing to take over more front to the right of our last sector, relieving the 5th Div. We moved to a place on the Wycheate-Kemmel road & to-morrow we go up to the line on our new sector just to North of Messines.

Monday 25 March

This morning early we moved up to the front to the N. of Messines & E. of Wyscheate. The front is very quiet indeed & is a network of tram tracks. The German fortifications are great, consisting of dozens of concrete pill boxes.

Of course this ground was taken from him in
Entry.84:
From our post the R.A.P., a great view is to be had of the ground now in German hands & many villages can be distinctly seen with the naked eye. No news of the German offensive.

Beautiful Spring weather.
Entry.85: Ye Gods! an officer has just told me that the fighting in the offensive is now taking place in High Wood ! Somme. It speaks for itself to anyone who knows the country. However, I believe the Bosche has paid heavily for his great advance, which compared with ours of the last two years has been lightning like.
Entry.86:
Second anniversary of our seeing France, the town & beautiful harbour of Toulon. Papers & information from G.H.Q. confirms the rumours of the German advance, as far as High Wood, Bernafay. Ye Gods, the papers report that a German gun is firing on Paris from a distance of 75 miles. Glorious day & very quiet on our front.

A Fritz ‘plane came over our lines last night & to-night & flew very low indeed & still he is O.K.
Entry.87: Wet & miserable today. News to-day of the Arras-Quentin-la Fere, battle is disconcerting & our line is now west of the old line from which we attacked in 1916. In fact Albert is in German hands. The offensive began on 21st inst. Fritz is shelling our vicinity with gas just now.
Entry.88: Good Friday. Wet. Last night Fritz shelled about here fairly heavily catching a battery. We had two trips out & much gas was in evidence.
Entry.89: Wet & miserable to-day but still very quiet on the front. A German airman very daringly came very low over our lines & escaped scot free. News from the Somme still disconcerting & the advance is in one place 25 miles deep & in another 15 miles from Amiens.
Entry.90: Still particularly quiet on the front, but it is said that there is a raid coming off to-night. There is a German Labour Battn. holding the line opposite us. This month has been a month of wonders, & the Ludendorff Offensive which now is twenty five miles deep from La Fere to Montdider, & now the Germans are ten miles from Amiens & can shell the Amiens-Paris railway. Prisoners are 70000 & Guns 1100, according to Berlin & in my opinion & in spite of expressions to the contrary, the British High Command was caught napping. Then the new era in guns, the shelling of Paris from 75 miles distance, is a wonder to be wondered at.
Entry.91: Glorious day. Raid never came off. We were relieved this afternoon & are now back at the Brasserie. Of course there is no doubt as to our next move which in my opinion to the Somme, where still heavy fighting continues. This is the first time I have felt genuinely sorry to leave the line. So quiet & happy we were. Easter Monday & April Fool’s day, caught nicely. Rather curious to see an Australian saluting an English Colonel in sight of the enemy at R.A.P.
Entry.92: Glorious day. Move from the Brasserie & joined up the unit at Reninghelst & move again on to Hoograf just on the outskirts of Poperinghe. There are few troops in this area but much movement is in evidence presumably up & down to the Somme, where things have quietened a little. The propogander for saving food etc., has been extended to areas in France in occupation of British troops, in shapes of notices to "Eat Less & Save Shipping" & many others. A walk round some of our old haunts round in Poperinghe. A very amusing incident to-day. We bearers were .
Entry.93:
AprilWet to-day.

A walk round to Remi Siding & round the district. The view of Poperinge through the trees & hop poles & across the waving wheat fields is fine, exactly what I pictured of Flemish scenery. This is the third time I have been in this district & I like it, in spite of its flatness & occasional objectional smell caused by the manuring of the fields. Nothing doing on the Somme but we entrain for there soon.
Entry.94:
Still wet & cloudy.

A walk round old haunts round Poperinghe.
Entry.95: Still wet & prospects of more rain. A walk round to Remi Siding & a look over the grave yard at the C.C.S’s which grew very much as the result of the Ypres stunts.We move tomorrow &entrain for the Somme where things seems to be livening up for a German attack.
Entry.96:
What luck. After many days rain to-day is fine for moving. We marched from Hoograf to Godewaersvelde where we entrained. The march lay along the base of the Mont des Cats & I was on the wheel stretchers – pack. Godewaersvelde of course is in France. At 2 a.m. we are now at Amiens on the Somme & Fritz is about eight-ten miles out towards Albert & St. Quentin. A journey, via St. Omer, Calais, Boulogne & Abbeville was made in cattle trucks. Our billets are about 4 kilos out on the Abbeville road.

The City of Amiens is full of inhabitants from villages within the new danger zone & they naturally think things are very black. In a big attack last week four uhlans were seen in here & repulsed by Armoured Cars!! Marvellous how they got through.
Entry.97: We are now at Longpre – not where we were in
Entry.98:
- on Somme River and about five miles or so from Amiens. The country about is looking well and the Cathedral looms out from here, dominating everything about. We marched through the town last night & arrived here at 5 a.m. It was a weird march, no lights except an occasional torch flashed on to the tall houses on either side of the road, the waggons rumbling over the cobbles & raining occasionally. Fritz is only nine miles from the town & I suppose the inhabitants are on pins & needles over the issue which centres round the town. This village & the towns & villages about are full of refugees. Yesterday the Bosche advanced three miles & took Bresle & heavily attacked the Australian front but was repulsed. He is shelling the towns about here from sounds, presumably Amiens. It is sad to see old couples, with their belongings in handkerchiefs on the road to Abbeville. Beautiful day. No orders yet until 4 p.m.

Monday 8 April

Still at Longpre-les-Amiens. The day is wet & miserable, but I managed to go for a dry walk along the bank of the Somme. It is a shame to see the people, old & young, coming out from Amiens with their belongings on their backs & barrows etc.

Last night fine, the Bosche bombed all round this district & yesterday he shelled Amiens. The artillery work last night & to-day was heavy & the bursts from German shells were distinctly audible. The people about here have very little faith in the English Army from their remarks. The French General Fayolle is now the man as by his strategy he saved the French left, which was jeopardized by the English withdrawal.

Much traffic on all lines of railway.
Entry.99:
Wet to-day. This afternoon to Bertangles, north of Amiens about nine kilometres.

We are camped under canvas on a decent hill overlooking the biggest airdrome I have yet seen. Heavy bombardment on the front from early morning & is going now & extended back as far as west of Amiens.
Entry.100:
Ye Gods, Fritz has attacked in the north about Fleurbaix, etc. & captured Saily sur la Lys, Laventie & Estaires. The bombardment, very heavy continued until early this morning on this front & was very intense. Wet off & on to-day & a walk to Villers Bocace. Fritz is marvellous!!! The above is so far only a rumour confirmed by Corps H.Q., & I cannot say on what front he has attacked. Our camp here is very decent, but there is no water. Whilst we were in bed to-night we were warned with tragic suddenness to be ready to move in the morning to entrain for the north.

Thursday 11 April

Glorious day & very warm. Artillery livened up to-day on this front.

Yesterday’s rumour has been confirmed by the English papers. We are not moving to-day but perhaps to-morrow, entraining for the north. The casualties of the Australian Divisions, 3rd & 4th on this front have been very heavy indeed but they have acquitted themselves magnificently, repelling attacks & charging brilliantly with fixed bayonets.

Gen. Gough in charge of
Entry.101: Army has been recalled over the initial failure to hold Fritz on his front. Had to bivouac to-night & it rained for about 30 minutes. What a short sojourn to the Somme!!
Entry.102: Move from Bertangles this morning, on to Amiens where we are to entrain this afternoon for the north. The front of the Bosche’s attack has been extended to twenty miles from La Bassee to the north. Things here are fairly quiet but he has been shelling Amiens heavily both to-day & yesterday when he put two into the Cathedral. "O to have seen what I have seen" to-day in marching through Amiens. Many houses have been knocked rotten & all over the place one passes one or two belated refugees with their belongings on their back & on various modes of conveyance. The roads are crowded with refugees & it makes one more sad than ever over this business. We entrained at Amiens & drew out of the town for a couple of hours. Beautiful night & the German ‘planes came over in droves dropping many bombs. One brought down.
Entry.103: Now just out of Hazebrouck where we detrain after coming up via Doullens, St. Pol & Lillers. Things up here are very confused & rumours are current as to the extent of the advance. Some say the fighting is now round Merris & Strazeele. We are forming an A.D.S. immediately. All along the railway line are signs of recent bombing by the Germans. The A.D.S. is at Borre on Hazebrouck-Ballieul Road & the Australians dug in on the Strazeele heights immediately after marching off the train. The Guards & 29th Division are here, the men of the latter being very drunk & disorderly.
Entry.104:
A rotten North wind to-day. No news from the line. Still near St. Sylvestre Cappel, 4 or 5 kilos from Hazebrouck. Everywhere you see troops who have been lost & at the 1st A.C.C.S., things were left in an awful hurry. Line seems to be Nieppe Forest Estaires-Merris-Steenwerke, Ballieul being still in our hands. French troops are in the vicinity.

The vicinity still throngs with refugees, poor beggars, young & old, living in tents under tarpaulins anywhere along the road.
Entry.105:
Move again to the northern outskirts of Hazebrouck where we are in very good billets.

Fritz is shelling round about causing much consternation among the remainder of the poor civilians who still persist in clinging to their homes. Good God it is pitiful to see them!!

Two casualties to Ambulance, Gleeson died of wounds, Clareson wounded. Yesterday the Bosche attacked our front, with all his transport following closely behind his infantry expecting an easy break through. What a shock he received!! Our M.G’s simply mowed him down at 100 yards range & scattered his transport in all directions. He evinced great surprise on meeting Australians, so two prisoners taken. To our brigade about 1000 Tommy stragglers are attached.
Entry.106: Our people are to attack to-night in conjunction with the French. We have been sent up to A.D.S. at Borre as reserve bearers. Quiet just now. Rumour has it that Fritz has driven the British back to a kilo from Ypres and captured nine hundred guns. Of course we, the 1st, are the only Australian Division on this front.
Entry.107: Fritz is shelling heavily all round this morning & we have now learnt that he attacked heavily but was beaten back. We are now up the line, plenty of work but things have quietened down again. "We are living in a farm" which has been left by the owners with all their property in kind & chattels all over the place & we have prospects of living on pork, fowl, etc. Our front is somewhere about Merris, Ballieul, Meteren & is covered with roaming stock, cows, goats, etc. It makes one heart bleed to walk through the deserted rooms of this house where everything is topsy turvy, & see little articles of feminine fancy tossed in all directions, visiting cards, etc. & I thank God that Australia is where it is.
Entry.108:
Things to-day have been very quiet indeed & we have been at the R.A.P. since 2.30 a.m. & have had no case. Meteren, or the vicinity is on fire & the shelling on the left, French front, has been heavy. I cannot get any definite information as to who holds Meteren. The French 75’s are very busy just now. Ninety per cent of the Boche’s artillery is small 4.2 & 77’s. Two prisoners last night, one officer & a corporal. No news from any other part of the front. Living well.

Heavy winds to-day.
Entry.109: Very sorry to be relieved from this post this morning as things were quiet & we were living exceedingly well. We are to work another sector of the line to be taken over from the French by the 3rd Bgde. & we are now waiting for the infantry to come in before we can take over the posts. We are now just to the left of Fletre with Meteren area. Ballieul is now in German hands. Things seem to have been very quiet just about here. "B" Section A.D.S. is at Caestre.
Entry.110: Early this morning we relieved the French at a R.A.P. to the left of Meteren. To-day things have been quiet, little shelling off & on & not a stretcher case has come through as yet. A bit of gas to-night. Caestre A.D.S. has been shelled & one case, Greenwood, wounded. A car was hit to-day but no one hurt. It is in the ditch at Fletre now, waiting for a first aid lorry. Fritz has excellent observation here.
Entry.111: Particularly quiet on the front all day. Glorious day & there has been much aerial work. Our post is just under the shadow of the Mont des Cats. Two stretcher cases from the line.
Entry.112:
To-day has been very hot round our Aid Post & Fritz has shelled us all day. He obtained one direct hit on our house & wounded one chap fairly badly.

A very heavy bombardment on our left. I think things will be quite warm about here in the future.
Entry.113:
Things have been quiet about here all day but to-night a heavy artillery activity was evident on the left. French front Battalions change over to-night & early in the morning there is a bit of a stunt in the direction of Meteren. Exactly what I cannot say.

Wednesday 24 April

Just after midnight this morning an attack was made on Meteren without artillery preparation by the 3rd Brigade. The Boche line was alive with machine guns & our men made good targets for the German Gunners in the moonlight. Ye Gods, it was a gutser! & our chaps suffered heavy casualties, mostly coming through this post. I have been carrying all day up till midnight. However, he left our roads alone & never shelled back at all. Again, this afternoon, the artillery fire on our left was terrific & on our front our people gave him some gas.

Thursday 25 April

Anzac Day, & the troops were liberally supplied with

1 pair socks

1 pkt. chewing gum
Entry.114:
pkt. cigarettes

Generous, eh.

Very quiet on the front all day but we hear rumours that the Boche has taken Kemmel Hill. Ye Gods it is marvellous. No doubt, the bombardments on the left for the last two nights were preliminary to the attack.
Entry.116:
Quiet to-day, no casualties all day.

News to hand that Kemmel Hill has been taken by the Boche after a big fight with the French defending troops.
Entry.117:
Last night the Boche shook things up round here & caused us much uneasiness with his shells. One direct hit on our cow shed. This afternoon too, he straafed here & dropped some 5.9’s on the road. Heavy bombardment on our left again to-night.

No casualties except two.
Entry.118:
We went up to the next post this evening for rations & found the place simply pock marked with new shell holes, & one direct on the farm house, causing two casualties to our chaps, poor "Comme ca" Clifford killed & Crocker wounded.

We have had no carries for the last 24 hours. Suckow too was wounded in Strazeele losing his arm.
Entry.119: Early this morning Fritz obtained another direct hit on our house but everyone was in bed & no one hurt. Otherwise everything has been quiet to-day. We were relieved to-night & reported to Caestre, where we were received by a hail of 5.9’s from Fritz. Move on again to H.Q. outside Hazebrouck.
Entry.120: Back at H.Q. near Hazebrouck where Fritz is shelling heavily round about. The day is cold.
Entry.121:
The Boche has been fairly quiet again to-day but what few he has sent over have landed close to our billett, "duds" everyone. Very warm. Playing cricket all day.

Hankin wounded up the line this morning.
Entry.122:
Still on the Northern outskirts of Hazebrouck, doing little else but play cricket all day.

Beautiful weather. A walk to Hondenghem this evening.
Entry.123: Still at the Northern outskirts of Hazebrouck, doing nothing. The heavies about here have been active & Fritz replies occasionally.
Entry.125:
In a cricket match to-day "B" Section were badly beaten by "All-Comers".

Fritz still shells these areas heavily in parts, Hazebrouck getting plenty as well as some gun positions on our left. Still civilians on this & other farms hang on.
Entry.126: Very wet this morning, but it was fine when we went into the line again to the same posts which we left. Things are quiet on this front to-night but on the left, the artillery is very active. Caestre is quiet now. The wheat flour & potatoes on the farms here are all being salved & taken back.
Entry.127:
Fairly quiet to-day except for the usual number of whiz bangs. Beautiful day.

Fritz is shelling Caestre again. Rumour has it that we go out with the Division to-morrow for a bit of a spell. Wild rumours are current about landings at Ostend, usual furffies of which this is typical.
Entry.128: To-day Fritz has been shelling all round the country, including Mont des Cats, obtaining direct hits on the Monastry. We are to be relieved to-night. Relieved to-night by Yorks & Lancs. & we got out without a casualty. Now back to Hazebrouck outskirts.
Entry.129:
A couple of days ago a curious incident happened in the air on this front. Owing to a Frenchman being out of his area, & not returning a Britisher’s signal, he was shot down by the Englisher & killed. Another Frenchman was brought down with a hole in his petrol tank. Both Frenchmen were good fliers. The Funeral of the Frenchman took place to-day from here, attended by Australian & French officers & men.

Quiet to-day. "B" beat "A" Section at cricket.
Entry.130: Glorious day to-day & we have been doing nothing but loaf round camp, playing cricket & football. Rumour hath it that we go to the line again to-morrow, on the Strazeele front, right of where we have just been relieved.
Entry.131:
Beautiful day.

This evening we went into the line to the right of where we were last & took over an R.A.P. at Strazeele station about five hundred yards from our front line. We evacuate along the railway line on trucks line 4 feet 8½" gauge. Things appear to be quiet here & so far shell fire has been practically nil. Three patients came in last night, two of whom died here. The country about which I know well is as flat as a pancake & the Boche has observation from Mont de Merris. We are living in a cellar of the house of a merchant of pommes des terres. Our first billet in France is only a couple of hundred yards north of here.
Entry.132: Wet to-day but very quiet on the front, & in spite of changing over, we had no carries.
Entry.133:
Beautiful day, & Aeroplane activity has been great to-day & to-night.

Fritz has been shelling off & on to-day & to-night but so far no casualties have resulted. We have spent the day in trying to make our place fairly bomb proof.
Entry.134:
Glorious day & things have been very quiet except for desultory shelling round about.

We are still living very well indeed. A very big gas attack is to eventuate shortly here, about 1200 projectors to be sent over. Since in the
Entry.135:
Battn. has had no stretcher case at all.

Thursday 26 May

Most glorious Sydney day to-day & the temp. was up very high. Practically no shells fired all day, but things livened up near the Gare de Strazeele to-night. Still no wounded.

Identification of troops opposing is wanted & perhaps a raid will be necessary to-morrow night. No raid is necessary now as identification was established by a Fritz being killed & his papers taken.
Entry.136: Glorious weather & still no cases. To-day Fritz has been shelling round about the station & has set fire to big stores, sheds & houses. In fact the fire about one hundred yards from here was a beauty.
Entry.137: Absolutely glorious days, now hot. We indulge in cold baths daily & enjoy them. I think this is about a record no stretcher cases since the 8th Battn. has been in. More fires in the vicinity to-day. Moonlight now & aerial activity day & night is great. In number of ‘planes up, ours are greatly in the majority. We are to be relieved soon, worse luck.
Entry.138: The 8th Battn. was relieved to-night after having done six days in the line with only one man wounded & he walked out. Still glorious weather & the country here is a blaze of colour, buttercups & daisies. The Boche has been shelling round about here again, but nothing close.
Entry.139:
Summer weather still continues & is simply glorious. We were relieved this evening & while we were coming out the Bosch gave us a hail of gas & H.E. shells.

Now back at H.Q. near Hazebrouck.
Entry.140: Down here, at Hazebrouck we lead the simple life and get round all day in shorts playing cricket & croquet. Bathing every morning after a mile run. Still glorious weather.
Entry.141: Kingcups, daisies and the "Bosom white of the hawthorn bud" are now making this district look simply glorious. Very hot & fine all day. Johno came back to-day looking well.
Entry.142:
Windy & gusty to-day.

An attack seems imminent on this front soon & it cannot be delayed much longer. I have an idea the high ground of Cassel-Mont-des-Cats-Mont Noir ridge will be the objective. Troops are coming up this evening. Still morning runs, baths & cricket, all day. The Bosch has been shelling about here a little to-day but Hazebrouck has been left alone.
Entry.143: Fine again & morning runs & showers & again in vogue.
Entry.144:
Big Aust. mail to-day, always the most welcome. Fine & playing cricket to-day.

An attack is rumoured to be made on Mont de Merris to-night. The Bosch has been shelling heavily all round the line with gas, perhaps preparatory to the second phase of the offensive.
Entry.145: Last night’s attack did not eventuate but the Bosch raided instead but was completely repulsed. He is shelling Pradelles & dist. heavily with gas which I think is a prelude to the second phase of his offensive. Glorious weather still prevails.
Entry.146: Glorious day again & things are quiet about here. We go up to the A.D.S. at Borre to-morrow.
Entry.147: All day to-day Fritz has been shelling the back areas with H.E. & Shrapnell & some fell in the vicinity of our billet. Across the fields a shell fell into the Q.M. Store of 3rd nucleus Battn. & caused five casualties. We go up to Borre to-night. News is to hand to-day of the re-commencement of the German offensive & he has attacked the French between Soissons & Rhiems. He had initial success, but I cannot say to what extent. Also North of here he attacked but only on a small front, where he penetrated our line. On this front our guns were busy last night but nothing happened.
Entry.148: At A.D.S. at Borre where things have been very quiet all day. To-night he burnt one of our balloons.
Entry.149: Last night Fritz burnt seven balloons about here, three French. Our people attacked this morning & succeeded in wresting some posts from the Bosch, but with about sixty casualties. Glorious day again. News from the South shows the Bosch has advanced ten miles & captured 15000 prisoners.
Entry.150:
Nothing of importance on this front. Another 1st Field man lightly wounded this morning.

"Bob" Goldrick mentioned in despatches. News from the Champagne shows Fritz to have Soissons & to have advanced about twenty miles almost to the Marne River.

He is truly wonderful wresting from the French the hotly disputed possession of last year of the Chemin des Dames which cost the French such casualties, in a day.

Even Paris is not absolutely safe.
Entry.151: Glorious weather still prevails. The Boshe has been shelling heavily with very heavy stuff on our left in direction of Caestre. He caused a couple of big fires. To-morrow night a stunt is expected, an attack on Mont de Merris, the post from where the Germans can observe very well the flat country below Strazeele. We most likely will go up. News from South is a little reassuring.
Entry.152:
News from the South shows us that the Boshe has reached the Marne & extended to the N.W. his attack to Noyon. We go up to-night in expectation of this projected attack.

12 midnight. We are up at R.A.P. waiting for the silence to be broken by our barrage. No shelling at all to-night. 
& things seem to be a bit
Heavy casualties are expected. Two more
Entry.153: Field men have been wounded, Bremmel & Gannon.
Entry.154: A wonderful success is the only term fit for this morning’s stunt. We were up the line & at 1 a.m. the barrage fell beautifully on to the Bosche line. All objectives were carried well to time & the result is that we now hold Mont de Merris & took prisoners over 300, ten trench mortars, fifteen machine guns & rumour hath it one field gun. Our casualties were wonderfully light, about one fifty including forty Germans going through Borre. Everyone concerned was highly pleased. Practically no shelling by Fritz & no counter attack. Glorious day. The
Entry.155:
& 11th Battns. were the attacking force, part only of 10th. The fact of the great number of prisoners is due to Fritz changing over when the attack started. The 29th Division on our right also did very well.

Tuesday 4 June

Still glorious weather & we are back at Borre, only to go up to-morrow evening for another eight days. The German prisoners who came through yesterday though very cheerful, were very poor specimens, 12th & 39th Reserve divisions. The habit of "ratting" them for their personal property, disgusting to say the least, was carried out by some thoroughly. Some of the incidents were very amusing.

Wednesday 5 June

Move into the line again, to the same post as previously, Strazeele Station. At midnight we had a carry & nearing the relay I was hit in the chest left side by a piece of flying metal. Narrow shave for the heart but it is only a scratch, however necessitating A.T. injection. Sent to Borre for a while.

Thursday 6 June

Up at the Aid Post again, but before I left Borre I saw the most thrilling air fight of my life. The Bosch, in a machine almost red, was endeavouring to elude four of our chaps & after most magnificent manouvering, very low down had to land at Hazebrouck. It is said that he has twenty three machines to his credit & apparently belonged to the famous "circus" formed by the late Richtoften.
Entry.156: Things are very quiet here to-day. There has been a 9.45 mortar put in position behind us & when it fires it will draw crabs.
Entry.157:
The "Tock Emma" fired to-day, a projectile 150 pounds in weight. From Strazeele heights a great view is to be had of the surrounding country almost back to Estaires. Quiet to-day with glorious weather. Several fires have been caused by shelling of farm houses.

Cook to-day.
Entry.158: Glorious weather still continues, & we are living very well indeed. The Bosch hit one of our outhouses early this morning.
Entry.159: Still living well on the fat of the land & enjoying glorious weather.
Entry.160: No event to break the rather pleasant monotony. A carry last night was uneventful.
Entry.161: Fine weather continues. Fritz remains fairly quiet though our people continually throw stuff over to his side. Only occasionally does he send much back. In the air, our ‘planes are much more in evidence than his & our observing ‘planes are always patrolling the front. To-night this Battn., the 7th is advancing about three hundred yards. Not many casualties expected.
Entry.162: This morning the 7th Battn. went over & took their objectives, three strong points killing about fifty Bosches & capturing another fifty. Our wounded numbered about thirty & we had about twenty Germans. Everything was wonderfully quiet until the last man had been got away & then Fritz opened up round our place with a big bombardment for about forty minutes. However, no damage. Relieved to-night & now at La Kreule, I with the "dog’s disease".
Entry.163: Put into our own little hospital to-day with a temp. of 103 deg; and feeling much off colour.
Entry.164:
Much better to-day & temp. is again normal, but very stiff and sore.

A big attack by the Bosche is expected to-night & amp; troops are being moved up to meet it. Our bearers are going up again as well some from the 2nd Field. In fact I think our people have rather reliable information as to the German’s movements on this front. Even on ½ mile of front where we were, three divisions were identified in eight days.
Entry.165: Absolutely nothing happened last night, except a bomb was dropped about a hundred yards behind my tent, catching five men wounded.
Entry.166: Still everything is very quiet. The country behind here is now very heavily wired & trenched in anticipation.
Entry.167: Australian mail to-day. The drought has been broken & for quite a good time we have had no rain. Out of hospital where I have been for the last seven days with the dog’s desease. This "dog’s desease", a kind of influenza or trench fever, has got a great hold on the troops and has been so for weeks past. In fact it must be playing up with the battalions and is quite an epidemic.
Entry.168: To-night a German aviator attempted to bring two of our balloons down but in so trying he met three of our ‘planes and was brought down in flames. Still fine weather.
Entry.169: A long walk to-day through Hazebrouck to Sercus, the first walk into civilization I have been for months. It is quite good to be able to talk to several very nice girls again.
Entry.170: Another walk to Sercus through Wallon Cappel, to see dentist who did a filling for me.
Entry.171:
Move up to A.D.S. at Borre. A stunt is coming off to-night or to-morrow night.

Still fine weather.

Sunday 23 June

Glorious weather & to-night a stunt is to come off to the left of Meteren as far as the 1st Aust. Division is concerned. Some Americans, with full packs have gone past here to-day, up to the line.
Entry.172: Last night we were sent up to 2nd Battn. R.A.P. at Molenaker in expectation of stunt. Full moon. At 12.30 this morning our barrage opened & in conjunction with South Africans on our left, two Companies of
Entry.173:
Battn. went over & successfully reached their objective, about three hundred yards. There were about forty casualties, including four Germans. The Bosch hardly fired a shot behind the front line.

We are now back at Borre again.
Entry.174: Except for light showers, weather continues fine. A walk to La Kreule this evening where there are Americans attached, two Sergeants and three Officers. Already they have introduced base-ball into the Ambulance. They went up the line this evening visiting posts & the Sergeants are attached now to Borre. Watching a 9.2" battery in action I was half surprised to see the shell soar away into the air.
Entry.175: Nothing eventful to-day at Borre except great rumours about the Austrian retirement across the Piave after their offensive is only six days old.
Entry.176: Nothing eventful all day, which is glorious. It is said that there is a hop over to-morrow morning.
Entry.177:
At 6 a.m. this morning our guns opened in a heavy barrage and an hour later the Tommies on our right went over & advanced about 3000 yards taking prisoners and guns. Our chaps followed up on their left at 10 a.m. and apparently linked up & it is rumoured that they took 40 prisoners and machine guns. Certainly prisoners were taken as we saw them come through Borre. Still glorious weather prevails. This evening Fritz is shelling between Borre & Pradelles heavily. Our American attaches went away to-day.

Ye Gods! the
Entry.178: did another hop over at 6 p.m. to-night and got all objectives, a subsidiary affair to the attack on the right by 31st Division. Casualties have not been extraordinarily heavy.
Entry.179:
Still glorious weather & at Borre to-night we moved up the line again to Strazeele Station again. Things have not been too quiet of late but everything is very still to-night.

This post is no good now because it has become H.Q.’s for battn. sigs. & they have almost ousted us from the post.
Entry.180:
At Strazeele Station R.A.P. where things have been fairly quiet except for shelling this morning when the Boshe attempted to raid the battalion on our left but came a Gutzer losing machine guns & prisoners. Our guns put up a ten minutes straafe at midday.

A ‘plane came down between the lines, one of ours with engine trouble, but both men are unhurt; they were 10000 feet in the air when the trouble showed itself & they volplaned down landing between two of our posts. Several cases have recurred lately of our shells hitting our ‘planes, being caught in barrages, men being of course killed. Also a couple of ‘planes have collided. A couple of cases last night.

Several of our own shells have been falling in our own line.
Entry.181: Another glorious day and fairly quiet, except for local shelling. An anti aircraft, German, did hit our house doing no damage. The Boshe forestalled our chaps in working on the ‘plane in no man’s land, getting up to it & taking portable parts away.
Entry.182: One case last night. Machine gun fire along our track is sometimes severe. Heavy shelling on our left this morning. Glorious day to-day. Living very well indeed.
Entry.183: No cases last night in spite of heavy shelling on the left Battn. who were raided but took prisoners & machine guns. Glorious weather. A raid by the 10th on our left is to come off to-morrow night. This Strazeele front is by far the most mentioned front on the line now & almost every night there is a raid on. Our division has held it for over 80 days, a record I think.
Entry.184:
Cooking to-day & all went well until the evening meal when on a sudden Fritz opened a barrage of H.E. & Gas shells. Nothing happened & marvellous to relate there was not one casualty in the line. Great aerial activity on both sides to-day. No cases last night. Of course the Boshe Barrage upset plans for the 10th & the raid is off.

News to hand of Australian success on the Somme at Hamel.
Entry.185:
On Thursday morning the Boshe raided 10th Battn. but he came a gutzer.

Very quiet all day & an Australian mail to-day. To be relieved to-morrow. Glorious weather continues.
Entry.186:
Absolutely quiet all day & not a shot fired by Fritz. Glorious day.

An American Sergeant was attached to this post & he is good to talk to.

The Australian ideas as to the American words of command were very amusing to him.

They were

Aust – Slope arms

American – Guys muskets on your shoulders put.

Aust – Eyes right or left

American – Guys look at ‘em

Aust – Attention

American – Guys stiffen

Aust – Stand at Ease

American – Guys Slacken

However, the Sergeant exploded all these ideas & was much amused.

Their words of command are similar to ours.
Entry.187:
As quiet last night & to-day as it was yesterday but cases came through, one buried by our 9.45 mortar falling short, another M.G. bullet. The American left us to-day.

To be relieved to-night.
Entry.188: Relieved last night and now at H.Q. Lakreule front where I went for a long walk through Hazebrouck & Wallon Cappel. The dog’s desease prevalent among the soldiers is also among the civilians & many of them are down with it.
Entry.189:
A bit of a scratch match at cricket to-day. To-night I went down to the "Sentimental Blokes" near Hazebrouck, & the concert was very decent. The girl was fine in fact she becomes more chic daily. A stunt is coming off to-night and we are standing by.

Wednesday 10 July

Raining to-day & thundery. The stunt of last night resulted in 30 prisoners & about 60 wounded for us. Visit 3rd Brigade Concert party.
Entry.190: To-day some of the 1st Battn. found Fritz asleep & went out and collected eighty of them & brought them in with only one casualty. They say it was done so quietly that the Germans in the rear are ignorant of the event, 4 p.m.
Entry.191: Wet and windy all day. Ye Gods the 1st &
Entry.192: Battns. are taking Bosches galore & the total is not about 150 and our casualties are very slight. In fact there is very little fighting over the matter at all.
Entry.193:
The country is looking well after the rain & I have just had a walk round Sercus & Wallon Cappel. Fritz was over bombing last night. A rest camp is opened for Australians at Bolougne & one is to go from the section, possibly myself.

Sunday 14 July

Wet all day. Fritzs ‘planes ‘were active last night bombing & his & our guns were busy to-day.
Entry.195: Move up to Borre A.D.S. again. News to hand of a new German attack North & South of Reims but I do not know the results. The 1st Aust. Division is being relieved a brigade at a time by 29th Division & they go back to Arques (Arces). The Tommies take over the right sector to-night.
Entry.196: Last night or early this morning rather the heat of yesterday was followed by a terrific thunder storm. Several of our bombing ‘planes were caught in it. To-day has been oppresively hot. Nothing happened on the front.
Entry.197:
Fearfully hot all day and one fully clothed is very uncomfortable.

News confirming the rumour of a German attack which has made little progress.
Entry.198:
Nothing of importance at all. Glorious weather after yesterday’s heat and rain.

Front continues quiet & in the South the Bosch seems to be held.

Friday 19 July

1stly on our front & on the left the 9th Battn. with the 9th Division went over & captured Meteren & 350 prisoners at 7.50 this morning. On the right a ‘labour’ battn. relieved the 29th Division & were caught changing over. About 50 casualties for the night. The German advance is held. Rumour is current that the French have made a counter offensive on a twenty five kilo front right flank on German right flank Chateau Thierry & have captured 17000 prisoners, 200 guns & advanced to a depth of
Entry.199: kilos. Seems very reliable. "Vive la France".
Entry.200: Wet & stormy to-day. Germans attacked one of our posts but came a "gutser", casualties are coming in. The news of yesterday’s rumour confirmed by paper.
Entry.202: Small stunts patrol work etc. on the front but only a few casualties. Fine day. Go up the line to-morrow.
Entry.203: Wet & miserable all day. Up at Strazeele Station R.A.P. again where the English troops are holding the line. They are labour men & are not fit to be in the line, little chaps & old men! They are very funny but are getting quite a number of cases already. Australian officers & N.C.O.s are attached to them to stiffen them & our chaps detest the job.
Entry.204: A few carries last night, sick & wounded. Wonderfully fine to-day & to-night & wonderfully quiet. These chaps are very funny here. Living very well indeed.
Entry.205: Wonderfully quiet. Have not heard a shell apart from the Archies.
Entry.206: Last night a platoon of this battalion were to take a strong post led by one of our officers. They failed & the only casualties were two Australians, both killed, the officer & a Corporal. Something fishy about it. Very quiet. Change over to-night for the Battn. in the line.
Entry.207: Last night the battalion here was relieved & changed over without a casualty. These men seem a better kind of men. North Staffs. relieve South Lancs. The doctor here R.A.M.C. is from Chatswood, Giblin. Very quiet on the front.
Entry.208: Rotten weather raining & stormy, but very quiet on the front. A game of bridge with the English padre to-night was very enjoyable. The ambulance is to be relieved in a day or so.
Entry.209: Quiet all day. A stunt for Merris to-night.,
Entry.210:
Last night the Australians on our left took Merris & established their line about 500 yards east of the village & took 150 prisoners. Our casualties were slight, six killed.

All day here Fritz has vented his wrath with shells, gas, H.E., causing us much inconvenience hopping down below every few minutes. No casualties. The Ambulance is not to be relieved, but we go out to-morrow.
Entry.211: A chap told us that he had it from Brigade that the Division is to be relieved on Friday. To-night Perkins told us that the Division is to be relieved in a day or so & we carry on here until to-morrow. Sudden!! We are going well back but me thinks to join the other Divisions on the Somme. Only four gas patients from all yesterday’s hostile shells.
Entry.212:
To-night we were relieved by a ambulance of 29th Division after this Ambulance doing line work for over 120 successive days which is a record for the Division or any other Division.

Now at La Kreule from where we march to-morrow in the direction of St. Omer.

Very quiet on the front to-day.
Entry.213: Move to-day from La Kreule to Racquinham 10 kilos from St. Omer & 7 from Aire, just west of the main St. Omer-Aire road. The day is the worst day we have had for months, raining continuously & we all got very wet indeed. The march was about 16 kilos but we are now out of the evacuated area & in civilization once more.
Entry.214: At Racquinghem, into which village I went for a walk this morning. This afternoon I went into St. Omer & walked round but the town is fairly dead. The gardens are very pretty. Very wet at intervals. News of a brilliantly successful attack from Rheims, the French retaking Soissons & I think that that front is our destination.
Entry.215:
Fine to-day.

A walk round the country this afternoon & the country is beautiful, cropped heavily & nicely timbered in the valleys. The view from the hill to the south includes Cyere Lillers & the slag heaps of Bethune.
Entry.216:
Nothing doing to-day but we are warned to move off in the morning at 12.45 to entrain at I think Wizernes for Longpre near Abbeville, where we are to join up our corps. Pictures to-night were decent. It is a ten kilo march to the station & the night is wet.

I hate wet night marches above anything.
Entry.217: On the Somme for the fourth time!!! At 12.45 this morning we moved from Racquingham to Wizernes about ten to twelve kilos & entrained & travelled via Calais & Abbeville to Pont Remy about 11 kilos form Abbeville where we detrained. We then marched about ten miles past our old billets at Bouchon, over the Somme, past L’Etoile to Vauchelles le Domart, where we billet for to-night. Although raining a little on the early march we did not get wet & this last march was in beautiful weather. A stunt is eminent & our division is participate even after over 100 days at a stretch on the Hazebrouck. I would be surprised if our ambulance does any part in this stunt, but on exactly what front, I cannot say.
Entry.218: This country is looking fine, rolling miles of crops and "roses are blooming in Picardy". This village is a typical Somme village, with a church a couple of estaminets & a few houses. Nearby is a Chateau where we are at a concert by R.A.F. We move to-night to just past Amiens. A big stunt is eminent. Have dinner with my little friend at Moulin Blue.
Entry.219:
The stunt came off & was a huge success so news from 4th Army says. Six miles deep is the advance & all objectives were taken ahead of time, tanks, cavalry, etc. operating. Heavens, Rumours are flying, but whatever happened has been a huge success. Australians, Canadians, British & French are at least participating.

We are on the move marching from Vauchelles to Saint Sauveur, on the Somme, just west of Amiens. Our route lay through fine country along Abbeville-Amiens road & we are getting, for a change, well fed. Fine day for march. We are now at St. Sauveur & here catch motor transport for Allonville. From St. Sauveur we travelled via Amiens (where there are yet some civilians) to Allonville, where we were over two years ago. Bivouac in the Chateau woods. Rumours about stunt are flying.

Bayonvillers. On Amiens- 
St. Quentin
 Nesle Rd.
Entry.220: Move again from Allonville to Corby, M.D.S. on the Somme, in which we had a swim. This place is just behind Villers Brettoneux & just to right and about five kilos ahead. Again to-night we moved further out across the country over which our troops advanced to an A.D.S. at Bay on villers. Heavens our troops have advanced & even now though five miles over the old German line, we are yet miles behind. Our marching to-day has been about fifteen miles & to-night Fritz is bombing & caught some chaps nearby. No shell fire much, but a number of casualties. Meet Roy Jamieson. All Divisions are in this & thousands of prisoners have been taken. The advance is about ten miles on this part, through villages of Warfuses, Bayonvillers & Harbonierre which of course have been smashed about.
Entry.221: Early this morning we moved up to Brigade H.Q. just behind a C.C.S. once used by us & taken by Fritz in his advance on March 21st. It is now in our hands again & standing. It is just near Rosieres taken by the Canadians yesterday. The front line is just over the ridge ahead of us, about ¾ mile on. Aerial activity is great, two planes probably Boshe, being brought down in flames this afternoon. I should say we are well over eight miles from our old front line. Fritz is now shelling locally & fairly consistently. Harbonierre is a village we passed through to-day not badly damaged.
Entry.222: Our front lies about 800-1000 yards east of the village of Lêhon, about five kilos along this road, Nesle-Amiens. Last night or this morning our people moved up again some distance capturing a few prisoners, some M.G.s & about six 77’s. Fritz replied with heavy shelling especially about here & our casualties were three, Groves, Ridgeway (serious) & Sgt. McRae. Also Sgt. Sellers was hit whilst we were coming in last afternoon. All day Fritz has been shelling the ridge ahead of us & his planes have been active downing one of balloons. Our people brought down two of his ‘planes in flames yesterday on this sector. Possibly move up further to-night & it is rumoured that there is a big stunt in the morning.
Entry.223:
Last night was fairly quiet, except for the four 6 inch guns in front of us, about fifty yards from us. Fritz shelled a bit using gas & H.E. but not much, last night & to-day.

The stunt did not come off. Australian mail very welcome. Another casualty. Prewer wounded, making five to date in this salient.
Entry.224:
Poor old Ridgeway died of his wounds. Wonderfully quiet all day, but very hot.

Several ‘planes have come down in flames & I think that one must have been ours.

A C.C.
 The village of Rosieres just on our right is one huge dump.
Entry.225:
A German ‘plane brought down by the A.A.’s this morning. Just now a Boshe plane chased one of our R.E. 8s old slow artillery observers extremely low down & brought him down about a hundred yards away. It was the coolest thing I have seen, two miles or more over our line but of course our plane had no hope at all. Very hot again to-day.

Fritz heavily shelling Vauvillers just on our left.
Entry.226: Still heavy shelling on our left. We are to be relieved to-morrow & already 4th Aust. Division & some Americans are up here. Quiet just here.
Entry.227: Move this morning at ten a.m. & march through the boiling hot sun & dust, heavens, it was dusty via Harbonierres, Bayonvillers & Warfuses to Vaux sur Somme & were very much refreshed by a swim in the river. Another of the chaps has died, Groves, very unfortunately. Bivouac for the night.
Entry.228: Indulging in early morning swims in the Somme. A walk along the river to Sailly le Sec which is badly battered about. Fine & warm.
Entry.229: Gloriously fine weather continues but everything is very quiet. News is scarce.
Entry.230: Glorious weather still. Walk along the river almost to Corbie & it is very pretty flanked with poplar trees.
Entry.231:
Glorious day & still at Vaux sur Somme, where we daily indulge in a swim in the river.

Glorious moonlit night. We move up again shortly.
Entry.232:
Very hot all day & I enjoyed a glorious swim in the river. Australian mail.

We bearers move up to-night on the South of the Somme in the vicinity of Proyart for a pretty big stunt.
Entry.233: At 10.30 last night we moved to a quarry on the outskirts of Mericourt sur Somme, where we arrived at 2 a.m. this morning. Everything is now quiet & the line is not too far away. Rumour hath it that some troops went over this morning & took Bray sur Somme. Certainly the artillery here was active. Very hot all day & Fritz has been shelling the village all day off & on. We are camping in the village, in a cellar, to-night.
Entry.234: At 4 a.m. or a little later our barrage opened & the 1st Division went over & advanced at least 3000 yards more likely more, but news is scarce & the actual result is indefinite. However, it was a success & over 3000 prisoners have been taken, many coming through our post & helping to evacuate the wounded. The wounded of course were many but not extraordinary & I believe Fritz shelled heavily but here in the back area I only heard about ten all told .Our casualties, all lightly wounded till now and Pearn, Cartaar, Bourke & Fritcroft, all lightly wounded. A big percentage of wounded were Boshes. Still at loading post Mericourt-sur-Somme.
Entry.235: A very quiet night. This morning we moved up to 4th Battn. R.A.P. in front of Chyvolles where yesterday there was plenty of work, but everything is quiet to-day & in fact we have a Ford car right up here. A good dugout, old French, about a kilo or so over the old front line & dug in the leeward of a good hill. Spasmodic shelling but no casualties.
Entry.236: Shelling off & on all day & a few cases but of course taken by the ford except a few this morning & one to-night in the pouring rain. We are now just to the right of & behind Chignes to the South of the Somme River. Prisoners are now estimated at 2,400,000 unwounded & our casualties were not remarkably heavy for the extent of the stunt, & it was most successful.
Entry.237: Fine` to-day & very quiet. We, the Division, is to be releived to-night. Rumours of big offensive all along British line & part of French are current. A big blow is supposed to be struck here to-morrow. Just up the Chignes road is a tremendous German gun which I had a look at to-night. It is about 15" with very long barrel & its mountings etc. are enormous. Guns are being moved up to here, quite close to the line.
Entry.238: At Morcourt sur Somme where we are to rest for a few days just behind the new balloon line. We came out last night & everything is very quiet. Our Division’s advance is highly mentioned in the papers & also is the 15" gun I saw yesterday. I expect we will be in again in a week.
Entry.239: Wet to-day but find time to go for a walk round the hills overlooking the Somme & villages of Cerises & Chipilly. Our line here has been advanced again & is the right flank of the 50 mile attack to the North. Aquatic sports to-morrow.
Entry.240: Aquatic sports this afternoon in a pond just off the river were very decent, "A" Section taking all honours with their best men, Green, Pollet & Barton. Rumour says that Peronne has fallen to our troops to-day.
Entry.241:
A dinner to-night in the church at Morcourt which was a tremendous success with a 1st Battn. band in attendance & the distribution of the prizes won yesterday. It is absolutely the best unit dinner in history. In responding to a eulogy "Bib" said "that we had a good dinner to-night ‘cos the rations came from the canteen & regimental funds but to-morrow when I get the rations from the Q.M. stores I will be a b—". Very funny indeed.

Rumour of a great attack in the south by American troops & others in two days time.
Entry.242: September weather showery off & on. Went to see some captured German guns, 8", 5.9’s, all of which have sent shells back to their late owners. On guard to-night.
Entry.243: Nothing doing here at Morcourt which is now miles from the war. In fact we can’t hear the guns & can only just see the balloons.
Entry.244:
A walk this afternoon to Proyart from where our division hopped off last stunt.

There are now two C.C.S.’s there now. Saw a number of German guns including three 5.9 navals in position. Changeable weather. On our front Mont St. Quentin & Peronne have been taken.
Entry.245:
Nothing doing here. Weather changeableRumour that we go in the line on Friday.

British still advance into the Hindenburg line.
Entry.247: Rumour that we move up to the line to-morrow which is now a great distance from here.
Entry.248: Move to-day from Morcourt to Halle on the Albert-Peronne road. We came by Bray, Suzette & Maricourt & we are now camped in a quarry, just north of the Somme & on the old Somme battlefield of 1916. The country is desolate just as it was when we were at Flers in 1916. Rumour that Fritz was driven back yesterday & the A.D.S. even is about 3½ kilos East of Peronne. Just on our left is Mont St. Quentin, not much of an eminence but commanding all approaches to it.
Entry.249:
Fine day with a swim in the Somme just W. of Peronne. This afternoon a walk to Mont St. Quentin over which the French had to fight in 1916-17 & which our chaps had a victory a week ago. It is a dominating position over looking the ruins of Peronne about a kilo away & the river. It is well fortified but literally strewn with German dead.

The Balloons moved forward to-day so our line must have advanced. We move to-morrow to Doignt, on river Cologne, S.E. of Peronne.
Entry.250:
Move this morning to Doignt about four miles. Our route lays through the outskirts of Peronne, which is badly knocked about. Peronne is a moated town of great historic importance, Quentin Durward etc. Wet to-day. Living in a cellar in a decent one time concrete houses. A walk round the village cemetry shows where the Germans have opened up tombs & taken the metal from coffins. In one the body (half decomposed) is lying in full view & bones are to be seen all over the place.

Transferred from bearers to clerical duties.
Entry.251: Move this afternoon to Buire where we are to establish a M.D.S. in bow huts which our people built in 1917 & had to evacuate again. About nine kilos from the line.
Entry.252: Working about M.D.S. fixing things up generally for work. The division takes over to-night at midnight & our bearers are already up, with the battalions.
Entry.253: Last night the Boshe bombed, causing many casualties. Take over new duties, in A & D room. The 4th Battn. had a stunt this morning, but was unsuccessful taking their objective but being shelled out again with a good number of casualties.
Entry.254: Wet off & on all day. Very few casualties to-day.
Entry.255:
Last night the A.D.S. retired to Tincourt because of shelling. Fine day & night & the Boshe bomb-birds were very busy but not without opposition. It is great to see the plane caught in a dozen lights from all round, shining like a great moth with archies bursting all round & tracer bullets going up from our M.G.s. One brought down in flames & another under apparent control both throwing out plenty of flares.

Score 1 for archies!!
Entry.257: Not very busy to-day or yesterday & nothing at all happened to break the usual routine of M.D.S. Railway broad gauge is now past here.
Entry.258:
A big stunt is impending on this front, to come off in a few days.

Glorious night, moonlit, with Boshe ‘planes in dozens.
Entry.259:
Last night a night of incidents. In a motor ride to C.C.S. at La Chapelete we got lost & went all over the country in moonlight. Fritz bombed the other side of the village (Buire) causing casualties including killed. A most terrific storm flooded me out my place in hut.

Fritz shelled the camp area causing us to take refuge in dugouts. The big stunt is for to-morrow & we expect to be very busy. Dummy tanks are to be used to draw fire from the Boshe.
Entry.260:
Early this morning, after a beautiful barrage, our chaps went over in part of a general attack & advanced about 6 kilos taking 1500 prisoners, 14 field guns & many M.G.s. Our casualties for the day, 1st Division are 43 & very light. Belleux & Hargicourt were taken by our brigade.

Plenty of work at M.D.S.
Entry.261:
Many men leave this week for Australia on a six months furlough stunt. Lucky beggars.

The 1st Aust. Division now holds two records, 1. holding the line continuously for about 130 days, (2) the record for the greatest numbers of guns & prisoners captured in one day by one division.
Entry.262: A walk this afternoon to Tincourt over the hills. A small stunt is coming off in the morning & then the Division comes out for a good long spell.
Entry.263: Americans are appearing on this front & soon we are to be relieved & I think for a good long spell behind the war area.
Entry.264: Amid much handshaking & good wishes fourteen 1914 men left the unit for Australia this morning. In the Orderly Room as "A" section clerk from to-day. Wet.
Entry.265:
To-morrow we are to move to Herbecourt preparatory to entraining for the West of Amiens.

Yanks why they are here by thousands the 30th Division relieving us. Tanks are also here by the 
the
 dozens & soon I think the Hindenburg line is to be attacked & I think carried by the enthusiastic Yanks.
Entry.266: Glorious day. Move to Biaches or remains thereof via Peronne & thence across river at Halle. Good march on good roads. Possibly entrain to-morrow.
Entry.268: Move from Biaches, marching to La Chapelette & after awful delay, by train via Brie, Chaulnes, Rosieres & Amiens to Longpre where we detrained. An awful journey partly in open trucks.
Entry.269: Early this morning we arrived at Pont Remy where we are now living. We have been house hunting all day, funniest experience imaginable & finally got a nice room with nice people. This village on the river is pretty, 8 kilos from Abbeville but is full of all kinds of people, including W.A.A.Cs. Thank Heaven for a sight of civilization again.
Entry.271: Visit Abbeville to-day by train & walk home along the road. Abbeville has been fairly extensively bombed & knocked about but we found a fine hotel for dinner & visited
Entry.272: A.G.H. having the d’apres midi with Miss Murdoch, Eric Grenville’s friend.
Entry.273: Usual routine at Pont Remy & walks around the village.
Entry.276: Glorious day & Pont Remy & the river is looking well. Thirty three originals left for home this morning. To-morrow I go on leave to England via Calais.
Entry.277: At Bolougne in rest camp after a decent days journey, En route for my leave to England. Quite a decent day & evening in Bolougne. Go to Calais to-morrow & embark there.
Entry.278: Crossing Calais to Dover rough. Dover to Victoria St. & get a glimpse of Canterbury Cathedral. Charing Cross Hotel. Accommodation is hard to get, the Strand Palace & Hassells Hotels being crowded.
Entry.279:
Church, Dr. Jowat. Richmond for the afternoon & evening. Once back in London one feels that one has never left it so completely does it banish France from the mind.

Of course rationing is in force, but there is no shortage of food.
Entry.280:
Windsor all day. "The Boy" at night. Windsor & 
Eato
 Eton is a fine & scrupulously clean town. The Castle is fine & the view therefrom, of the river & the country for miles is glorious. Eton College stands out well.
Entry.282: Arrive in Edinburgh on a wet day but still can do the Castle, Royal Mile & the Holyrood Palace, all places abounding in history. The Royal Mile however, loses all its historical beauty, by the awful condition of the people living there. George Hotel.
Entry.283:
Another walk round the lower part of the Royal Mile to Holyrood Castle.

Edinburgh is the finest city I have yet been in, a city of liesure, learning & refinement. Business is not brisk & the Streets are seas of smiling faces. The general opinion of the people I have met is to have no peace until the Germans are thoroughly defeated.
Entry.284: Forth Bridge by a char-a-banc. The drive is very fine indeed & the country & autumn colouring in the trees are glorious. The Bridge impressed me very much & is a tremendous structure. "Fair & Warmer" this evening.
Entry.285:
Arrive in Glasgow & at once start sight seeing. The Rouken Glen & Botanic Gardens & then University & Art Gallery. Glasgow, in great contrast to Edinburgh, is a city of business, many people in the streets. There are signs of sedition here too, & many seditious notices are chalked about the pavements.

Blythswood Hotel.
Entry.286:
A fine day but not clear. A visit to Loch Lomond, Balloch, but no steamers running.

No doubt, the lake is beautiful, but I was far from being moved when I saw it. Possibly expected too much. Balloch Park is very fine. A walk round Glasgow this evening in a crowd of people of which I have seen no equal.
Entry.287:
"The first thing which I remember as an event in life was being taken by my nurse to the brow of Friars Crag on Derwent Water." John Ruskin. Arrived at Keswick on Derwent water from Glascow, via Carlisle & Penrith this afternoon. Friars Cragg & Castle Head, are spots glorious, both commanding views of Derwentwater & the latter of the finest panorama I have yet seen in my life. The run down from Glasgow is great, crossing & re-crossing river after river & the colouring of trees & bracken is glorious.

Royal Oak Hotel.
Entry.288: An all day trip to Buttermere & Crummock lakes. This country the poets country is all I expected it to be & I cannot say more. This trip is unique along the Borrodale Valley & over the Honister pass, back via Devils Elbow. One walks over the Honister Pass but it is well worth it. The hills crisscrossed with many waterfalls, red with drying bracken & the colouring of the trees is magnificent.
