Entry.289: Another fine day & drive to Ambleside on Windermere via Thirlmere, Grasmere & Rydal waters. Grasmere is very pretty indeed & one gets a view of Wordsworth’s Cottage & Seat. Thirlmere is now the source of water supply for Manchester, but the Lake is not all spoilt. The drive is very fine past Helvellyn, but not as much
Entry.291: In London in the thickest fog I have yet been in. Shopping etc. all day. Dinner at troc. & to the "Maid of the Mountains" in the evening. Return to France to-morrow.
Entry.292:
Leave Victoria St. at 9 a.m. & cross to Calais from Dover. Crossing fine.

Now at rest camp at Calais.
Entry.293: Entrain at Calais & travell to Etaples by an awful train arriving after six hours journey & put up for the night at rest camp.
Entry.294: Arrive back at the unit at Pont Remy after travelling from Etaples to Longpre & having to walk back to Pont Remy at night.
Entry.295:
At Pont Remy again on usual routine work in the orderly room.

Will’s arrival in England while I was on leave.
Entry.297: Visit Monflieres & look over the very interesting Chapel to which much tradition is attached.
Entry.298:
Visit L’Etoile 
Pont Remy
 for the day & made quite a decent day of it.

Fine weather.
Entry.300: This afternoon & evening at Abbeville, mainly to have a good dinner.
Entry.301: Usual routine at Pont Remy in Orderly Room. Glorious weather just now & the colourings in the trees along the river & elsewhere are very fine indeed.
Entry.304:
At Pont Remy. Nothing of importance.

Notes of October

Just here it is as well to note that there is a peculiar disease flourishing throughout all Europe & has been for months past. It is a severe influenza, or in French, "Grippe Espagnol". It is more than influenza but how much more the medical men cannot say.

England, France, Germany & Spain have been very severely afflicted & the troops are also suffering from the epidemic. The % of mortality is very high & American soldiers arriving in England are liable to it. This month the Educational Scheme has become part of the daily routine of the Ambulance.
Entry.305: News of the capitulation of Turkey as from noon
Entry.306:
Toussaint. All Pont Remy & in fact France is out to-day in its best, to honour by a church service the dead.

Saturday 2 November

News of the armistice between Austria & Italy. We are to move shortly & go up to the line, which news is a shock to me.
Entry.307: Still at Pont Remy, but I think we move up to the line on Wednesday. Rumours of an armistice with Germany are current.
Entry.308: The funniest night for years. Rumour hath it that a French town crier has said, officially, that an armistice has been signed with Germany. All the village, soldiers & civilians are rejoicing, but I think prematurely. However, I have had a glass of wine with my Parisienne for the occasion. We move to-morrow. O Ye Gods!!!! if it is only true!!!
Entry.309: Move cancelled & we move to-morrow, our final de-training station being Epehy, just west of le Catelet. We entrain at Hangest. Absolutely nothing in yesterday’s rumours which were getting a good hold in Pont Remy. Wet to-day.
Entry.310:
Wet again & prospects looked rotten for a move. However, after having packed & even fallen in one parade, an order came, say no movement of troops is to take place to-day. Postponed for at least 24 hours. Good news from the front, the Germans retreating 
for
 on a 70 mile front.
Entry.311: After three parades to-day, much to the amusement of the villagers, we finally moved by march route to Villers-sous-Ailly, six or seven miles, where we are now billeted in a huge barn. Oh, we miss our beds of Pont Remy. Peace is in sight!! German delegates have crossed line to confer with Foch on armistice terms.
Entry.312: March from Villers to Hangest where we entrain & move off en route to Epehy, just north of Roisel.
Entry.313: Ye Gods! we have only reached Epehy this evening after thirty hours to do 90 miles. In fact one stop lasted at Roisel for 7 hours. Epeny is of course just West of the Hindenburg System & the country is devastated.
Entry.314:
Move from Epeny to Baseul, on the le Cateau-Landrecies Road, about three kilos East of le Cateau. Move by bus, most interesting, over the old Hindenburg System of defences, where barely a wall stands, till we came to a country of green crops and civilians, who were liberated from the Germans in the recent advance. Le Cateau is a fair sized town indeed but badly smashed about, and there are still civilians there, as also in this village.

But where is the war? Here even, we cannot hear a gun or see a flash & we are twenty miles East of Cambrai. Personally I think the Boshes have bolted!! News from H.Q. says Kaiser has evacuated & Socialists are in power in Germany.
Entry.315: At 11 a.m. this morning, 72 hours given to German delegates to sign armistice expires. I wonder what will be the news to-day in view of yesterday’s news. The day we have been looking for for years has come and hostilities cease at 11 a.m. to-day on the whole western front. A walk round the country to Ors & Catillon, where there are civilians still living, though very poor indeed. The shelling round some of the villages has been severe, & where the civies got while it was on I don’t know. We, the 1st Division, are to represent the Aust. Corps in the march through liberated Belgium, following the Boshe back to his own country. It takes some believing but is nevertheless official.
Entry.316: At Bazeul on the le Cateau-Maubeuge Road. We are moving to-morrow, moving back & rumours are rife that we are en route for Marseilles & thence to Turkey.
Entry.317:
Early this morning we moved, back to Busigny, a march of nine miles or so. En route, we passed 4th Army H.Q. & while passing General Rawlinson came and had a few words with us. He told us that we were going to Busigny area until the railway was repaired to Germany & then we were to go on to Coblenz, on the Rhine!!! What joyous news.

New lands to discover & new people to see. Of course, yesterday’s rumours dispelled..
Entry.318: At Busigny enjoying glorious weather & not much work. A big Aust. mail in to-day.
Entry.319: Still at Bussigny. We are liable to move at any time to the Frontier, but I think that we will have to go on foot. We are having glorious weather & the moonlit nights are no longer feared for fear of visits of enemy ‘planes. We saw a very fine show to-night, the "Pedlars" & it is the best we have seen in France.
Entry.320: A walk to Maretz & a look over several of the ‘dromes in the vicinity.
Entry.321: Censorship regs. have to a certain extent been relaxed & cameras are now allowed to be carried.
Entry.322:
Fearfully cold to-day and our first glimpse of snow. Very little however.

Another evening at the Pedlars who are very good indeed. Great preparations are being made for this march to Germany.
Entry.323: Nothing doing, still at Busigny, where it is very cold.
Entry.324: Very busy to-day in anticipation of moving to-morrow, the beginning of our march to Germany. Very foggy & cold.
Entry.325: Beautiful day & at 9.30 we began our move to Germany, the first stage to Mazinghien about 8 miles being marched to-day. We are now at Mazinghien, a village badly knocked about. Rumours are rife that W.M. Hughes has objected to our going to Germany & that the move is being cancelled & we are going Home at early date.
Entry.326: Move on again about 8 miles to Prisches, a good march on a fine day. We have good billets at Prisches. were a walk to other villages where we were objects of curiosity as Australians had not been seen before. Move on to-morrow again.
Entry.327: Move again to Avesnelles, on the outskirts of Avesnes. The march was good, nine miles and day fine. Avesnes is a rather fine town, & shows little sign of being knocked about, except railway lines. The country here, Nord, is very fine, intense orcharding appears to be main industry. Of course business is not normal. The rumour that we don’t go to Germany, but only to Belgium, still holds.
Entry.328: At Avesnelles. A walk to Quesnes which has been quite a decent little town with a fine church. This morning some silly coot set fire to an old ammunition train and explosions have been going all day. Move again to-morrow to Solre le Chateau.
Entry.329: Move again to-day to Solre-le-Chateau, which is a decent sized town, about four miles from the Belgian Frontier. The steeple of the Church is rather imposing. Our billets, a one time German hospital are fine, all under one big roof. The march, about eight miles, was on wet roads but we had no rain. We are now in the area, evacuated by the Germans after the signing of the Armistice but even here the railways, cross roads & bridges have all been blown up by mines.
Entry.330: The country here, Nord, is fine & well forested & everyone seems to have been prosperous before the war.
Entry.331: Still at Solre-le-Chateau. From here I walked to the Belgian Frontier.
Entry.332: Still at Solre where we will remain for yet a few days. Our next stop will be at Charleroi where we will most likely spend Xmas. The church here is of Spanish origin having been built while the Spanish dominated the Netherlands in 14 & 15 centuries.
Entry.335: A walk round the Station & there a scene of desolation & wreckage is to be seen, scarcely imagined. Trucks & railway lines are thrown yards away & it is the greatest bit of destruction I have seen.
Entry.336: Fine day & I took advantage of it to run into Muageuge, the great Frontier fort of this district. It is indeed some fortress & the ramparts are very solid indeed. The streets are narrow & the town old fashioned.
Entry.337: Two lectures to-day, in connection with the A.I.F. education scheme, one by the Bishop Frodgem (?) on Democracy & one by Lieut. Lowe, the Educational Officer on the scheme generally. It is indeed some scheme & all is to be done to fit a man to recommence civil life.
Entry.339: Considering the time of year we are to-day having glorious weather, fine & clear & quite warm.
Entry.343: Jumped at the chance of a run to Charleroi to-day, though a bit wet and we had two punctures, we had a good day. Charleroi is a fine lively place & is going on as in pre-war days. Mining for coal is the great industry of this part of Belgium. The country en route, 36 kilos is fine & well cultivated. The town is en fete bedraped with flags & the people display great curiosity at us Australians thinking we are Americans. A debate to-night was very good. The women with hair cut short – the sign of the Boshe - & the Museum, are rather typical of the Continent.
Entry.345:
Though wet, the weather is remarkably warm, considering the time of year.

In fact we have only had a few days of cold weather as yet.
Entry.346: A trip on duty to Maubeuge in the driving rain was not pleasant.
Entry.347: We move on the 15th in two stages to the vicinity of Charleroi.
Entry.349:
Move this morning at 11 o’clock & arrive at Solre St. Gery this afternoon.

Solre St. Gery is just out of Beaumont & is a very quaint old village. We move on again to-morrow at 8 a.m. The country is fine, undulating & seems to be of great agricultural wealth & well inhabited. We are now out of France & in Belgium which is a different Belgium to Ypres!!
Entry.350: Move again to-day to Gourdinne on a very circuitous route via Walcourt, which is a decent small town. Wet. The country we are passing through is magnificent & very fertile & closely inhabited & cultivated.
Entry.351:
Move again to-day to our destination, Chateau Toussaint Gougnies which is on a high hill, commanding good views of surrounding country. The building is horribly cold and bleak & to-morrow we are to open an hospital just down the road. Weather rotten, cold, windy & wet.

Wednesday 18 December

At Hospital, where we have established a decent rest station but we are miles from Charleroi or any place of any size. The people here are wonderfully generous & will give us anything. I have a small room & bed with sheets, etc. Weather still keeps cold, wet & very windy & is miserable. We are now in the area of the atrocities of 1914. Entry.353: A walk to Mettet about four to five kilos away. The town is a decent small place & in the square are parked many Boshe guns.
Entry.355: Rotten weather, cold, windy & wet & there is not much to do in these parts.
Entry.356:
Another visit to Charleroi, about 17 kilos away, partly walking, then on a Belgians cart & thence by tram. The City on Sunday is very gay indeed & the streets thronged with people. Cafes, Cabarets & Picture houses in full swing & one, the Trianon café & picture house, is very good & typically continental.

Place brilliantly lighted at night.

However, coming home in the dark, wet, & windy, night getting very wet, partly a pied, & partly à cheval, was not too brilliant.
Entry.359: Xmas day passed quietly. We had much to eat & a little to drink, but everything was very orderly. As a matter of act, I have a touch of flu.
Entry.360: Joy! A return has been asked of all men who left Australia in 1915 & C.O.’s have been warned to be prepared to lose these men at any moment. Admitted to Rest Station with flu.
Entry.361: Most rotten weather, raining, windy & cold.
Entry.362:
It is very possible that we 1915 men will be enroute for home by the end of the next month.

Some men left to-day, up to the end of June.
Entry.364:
Discharged from Rest Station.

Still rotten weather. "Prince of Wales" in the vicinity dishing out M.M.’s to the troops.

Nothing doing at all. Dreary weather still continues. I am going to the Field of Waterloo to-morrow.

Rumours of return of all 1915 men next month are still running strong & they seem to be on good grounds too.
